citations.desc: Access and inspection of records and property; submission of itineraries.
citations.narrative:
The licensee’s representative verbally confirmed that the licensee is in intermittent travel status in Minnesota for one
month starting in April 2025. The licensee failed to provide an itinerary for travel status and locations to the Deputy
Administrator.
Failure to provide an itinerary at least two days in advance of overnight travel to any location other than the approved
home site results in the Department's inability to conduct an inspection to ensure the welfare of the animals covered under
the Animal Welfare Act.
Correct by April 18, 2025 by submitting a written itinerary to the Deputy Administrator. The itinerary shall include all
information required in this section, but not limited to, the names, dates, and locations (with addresses) where the animals
will travel, be housed, and be exhibited, including all anticipated dates and locations (with addresses) for any stops and
layovers that allow or require removal of the animals from the transport enclosures.

The licensee’s written program of veterinary care did not include information on dogs that the licensee is exhibiting. A
written program of veterinary care for dogs requires instruction on regularly scheduled visits, complete physical exams,
vaccinations, parasite sampling and control, and preventative care and treatments to ensure adequate veterinary care for
all dogs. Failure to have a written program of veterinary care for dogs may result in poor health and welfare management
of the animals.
Correct by May 1, 2025 by following an appropriate program of veterinary care for dogs that is developed, documented in
writing, and signed by the attending veterinarian.

Seven weaned rabbits were housed in an indoor primary enclosure that does not supply the minimum required space for
each rabbit. At the time of inspection, the rabbits were being housed in a plastic bottomed enclosure with wire sides and
top in a trailer to keep them warm. They were not in their larger enclosure that is used during public display. The floor
space in their enclosure provides approximately four square feet (sq ft) of floor space. The rabbits weigh less than two
kilograms (4.4 pounds) and therefore require a primary enclosure that supplies a minimum of 1.5 sq ft of floor space for
each rabbit and a minimum of 10.5 sq ft of floor space for this group of seven.
Not providing the minimum area of space does not allow for adequate freedom of movement or exercise, and may
increase the potential for injury due to overcrowding or competition between the rabbits.
Correct by April 18, 2025 by providing all rabbits at least the minimum required floor space (1.5 sq ft each) in their primary
enclosure. This minimum floor space is exclusive of space taken up by food and water receptacles.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with an authorized person.
n

narrative:
2.126(c) 
   
Access and inspection of records and property; submission of itineraries. 
The licensee’s representative verbally confirmed that the licensee is in intermittent travel status in Minnesota for one 
month starting in April 2025. The licensee failed to provide an itinerary for travel status and locations to the Deputy 
Administrator. 
 
Failure to provide an itinerary at least two days in advance of overnight travel to any location other than the approved 
home site results in the Department's inability to conduct an inspection to ensure the welfare of the animals covered under 
the Animal Welfare Act. 
 
Correct by April 18, 2025 by submitting a written itinerary to the Deputy Administrator. The itinerary shall include all 
information required in this section, but not limited to, the names, dates, and locations (with addresses) where the animals 
will travel, be housed, and be exhibited, including all anticipated dates and locations (with addresses) for any stops and 
layovers that allow or require removal of the animals from the transport enclosures. 
3.13(a) 
   
Veterinary care for dogs. 
The licensee’s written program of veterinary care did not include information on dogs that the licensee is exhibiting. A 
written program of veterinary care for dogs requires instruction on regularly scheduled visits, complete physical exams, 
vaccinations, parasite sampling and control, and preventative care and treatments to ensure adequate veterinary care for 
all dogs. Failure to have a written program of veterinary care for dogs may result in poor health and welfare management 
of the animals. 
 
Correct by May 1, 2025 by following an appropriate program of veterinary care for dogs that is developed, documented in 
writing, and signed by the attending veterinarian. 
3.53(c)(2) 
   
Primary enclosures.

Seven weaned rabbits were housed in an indoor primary enclosure that does not supply the minimum required space for 
each rabbit. At the time of inspection, the rabbits were being housed in a plastic bottomed enclosure with wire sides and 
top in a trailer to keep them warm. They were not in their larger enclosure that is used during public display. The floor 
space in their enclosure provides approximately four square feet (sq ft) of floor space. The rabbits weigh less than two 
kilograms (4.4 pounds) and therefore require a primary enclosure that supplies a minimum of 1.5 sq ft of floor space for 
each rabbit and a minimum of 10.5 sq ft of floor space for this group of seven.  
 
Not providing the minimum area of space does not allow for adequate freedom of movement or exercise, and may 
increase the potential for injury due to overcrowding or competition between the rabbits.  
 
Correct by April 18, 2025 by providing all rabbits at least the minimum required floor space (1.5 sq ft each) in their primary 
enclosure. This minimum floor space is exclusive of space taken up by food and water receptacles. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with an authorized person.

species.common: DOMESTIC PIG / POTBELLY PIG / MICRO PIG
